                                                            Our first Launch Week is over! See the recap ðŸš€

                                                            June 17, 2024

                                                            â€¢

                                                            Nicolas Camara

                                                            Firecrawl x Dify.AI: Add web data to your RAG applications

                                                            We are excited to announce that Firecrawl now integrates seamlessly with Dify, empowering your RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) applications like never before!

                                                            \n

                                                            Introducing Dify x Firecrawl

                                                            \n

                                                            Dify is an open-source platform for developing LLM (Large Language Model) applications. It allows you to orchestrate everything from simple agents to complex AI workflows, all powered by a robust RAG engine. With Firecrawl, you can now add web data to your RAG applications - all inside Difyâ€™s platform.

                                                            \n

                                                            Ingesting Web Data

                                                            \n

                                                            Firecrawl enables you to convert any website into clean, LLM-ready data effortlessly. To use it in Dify, configure your settings in the Knowledge dashboard. There you can set your Firecrawl API key and start crawing right away.

                                                            \n

                                                            \n

                                                            Easy Setup and Customization

                                                            \n

                                                            To start using it, pass the URL you want to ingest by clicking the Sync from website button in the Knowledge section. Tailor your crawling process with options to set sub-page limits and depths. Use the Exclude and Include path options to ensure you capture exactly the data you need.

                                                            \n

                                                            \n

                                                            Data Embedding

                                                            \n

                                                            Firecrawl rapidly crawls web pages in parallel. After crawling, you can select the desired web data on Dify for preprocessing and cleaning. The processed data is then embedded and stored in Difyâ€™s vector DB as a new knowledge base.

                                                            \n

                                                            \n

                                                            \n

                                                            Ready for production

                                                            \n

                                                            Now, you can create a RAG app that uses web data as contextual knowledge on Dify with the power of Firecrawl. We value your feedback! Connect with us on X/Twitter @firecrawl_dev.

                                                            Article updated recently

                                                            ðŸ”¥

                                                            Ready to Build?

                                                            Start scraping web data for your AI apps today.
                                                            No credit card needed.

                                                            Get Started

                                                            Nicolas Camara is the Chief Technology Officer (CTO) at Firecrawl. \n He previously built and scaled Mendable, one of the pioneering "chat with your documents" apps, \n which had major Fortune 500 customers like Snapchat, Coinbase, and MongoDB. \n Prior to that, Nicolas built SideGuide, the first code-learning tool inside VS Code, \n and grew a community of 50,000 users. Nicolas studied Computer Science and has over 10 years of experience in building software.

Weâ€™re excited to introduce an exciting new feature that will bring your web scraping projects to the next level: Real-Time Crawling with WebSockets.\n\n**Introducing Crawl URL and Watch**\n\nWeâ€™re thrilled to announce our new WebSocket-based method, `Crawl URL and Watch`. This powerful feature enables real-time data extraction and monitoring, opening up new possibilities for immediate data processing.\n\n**How It Works**\n\nThe `Crawl URL and Watch` method initiates a crawl job and returns a watcher object. You can then add event listeners for various events like â€œdocumentâ€ (when a new page is crawled), â€œerrorâ€ (if an error occurs), and â€œdoneâ€ (when the crawl is complete).\n\nThis approach allows you to process data in real-time, react to errors immediately, and know exactly when your crawl is finished.\n\nWeâ€™re excited to see how youâ€™ll use this new feature to enhance your web scraping projects and create more dynamic, responsive applications.\n\nCheck out our documentation for a detailed guide on how to implement `Crawl URL and Watch` in your projects: [Firecrawl WebSocket Documentation](https://docs.firecrawl.dev/features/crawl#crawl-websocket)\n\nArticle updated recently\n\n[ðŸ”¥](/)\n\n## Ready to _Build?_\n\nStart scraping web data for your AI apps today.\n\nNo credit card needed.\n\n[Get Started](/signin)\n\n[Talk to us](https://calendly.com/d/cj83-ngq-knk/meet-firecrawl)\n\n## About the Author\n\n[![Eric Ciarla image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/eric-img.jpeg)\\\\\nEric Ciarla@ericciarla](https://x.com/ericciarla)\n\nEric Ciarla is the Chief Operating Officer (COO) of Firecrawl and leads marketing.                                                               Our first Launch Week is over! See the recap ðŸš€

                                                              August 30, 2024

                                                              â€¢

                                                              Eric Ciarla

                                                              Launch Week I / Day 5: Real-Time Crawling with WebSockets

                                                              Welcome to Day 5 of Firecrawlâ€™s Launch Week! Weâ€™re excited to introduce an exciting new feature that will bring your web scraping projects to the next level: Real-Time Crawling with WebSockets.

                                                              \n

                                                              Introducing Crawl URL and Watch

                                                              \n

                                                              Weâ€™re thrilled to announce our new WebSocket-based method, Crawl URL and Watch. This powerful feature enables real-time data extraction and monitoring, opening up new possibilities for immediate data processing.

                                                              \n

                                                              How It Works

                                                              \n

                                                              The Crawl URL and Watch method initiates a crawl job and returns a watcher object. You can then add event listeners for various events like â€œdocumentâ€ (when a new page is crawled), â€œerrorâ€ (if an error occurs), and â€œdoneâ€ (when the crawl is complete).

                                                              \n

                                                              This approach allows you to process data in real-time, react to errors immediately, and know exactly when your crawl is finished.

                                                              \n

                                                              Weâ€™re excited to see how youâ€™ll use this new feature to enhance your web scraping projects and create more dynamic, responsive applications.

                                                              \n

                                                              Check out our documentation for a detailed guide on how to implement Crawl URL and Watch in your projects: Firecrawl WebSocket Documentation

[See the recap ðŸš€](blog/firecrawl-launch-week-1-recap)\n\nSeptember 1, 2024\n\nâ€¢\n\n[![Nicolas Camara image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/nick-img.jpeg)Nicolas Camara](https://x.com/nickscamara_)\n\n# Launch Week I / Day 7: Crawl Webhooks (v1)\n\n![Launch Week I / Day 7: Crawl Webhooks (v1) image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/blog/v1)\n\nWelcome to Day 7 of Firecrawlâ€™s Launch Week! Weâ€™re excited to introduce new /crawl webhook support.\n\n## Crawl Webhook\n\nYou can now pass a `webhook` parameter to the `/crawl` endpoint. This will send a POST request to the URL you specify when the crawl is started, updated and completed.\n\nThe webhook will now trigger for every page crawled and not just the whole result at the end.\n\n![Webhook](https://www.firecrawl.dev/images/blog/webhook-v1.png)\n\n### Webhook Events\n\nThere are now 4 types of events:\n\n- `crawl.started` \\- Triggered when the crawl is started.\n- `crawl.page` \\- Triggered for every page crawled.\n- `crawl.completed` \\- Triggered when the crawl is completed to let you know itâ€™s done.\n- `crawl.failed` \\- Triggered when the crawl fails.\n\n### Webhook Response\n\n- `success` \\- If the webhook was successful in crawling the page correctly.\n- `type` \\- The type of event that occurred.\n- `id` \\- The ID of the crawl.\n- `data` \\- The data that was scraped (Array). This will only be non empty on `crawl.page` and will contain 1 item if the page was scraped successfully. The response is the same as the `/scrape` endpoint.\n- `error` \\- If the webhook failed, this will contain the error message.\n\n## Learn More\n\nLearn more about the webhook in our [documentation](https://docs.firecrawl.dev/features/crawl#crawl-webhook).\n\nArticle updated recently\n\n[ðŸ”¥](/)\n\n## Ready to _Build?_\n\nStart scraping web data for your AI apps today.\n\nNo credit card needed.\n\n[Get Started](/signin)\n\n[Talk to us](https://calendly.com/d/cj83-ngq-knk/meet-firecrawl)\n\n## About the Author\n\n[![Nicolas Camara image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/nick-img.jpeg)\\\\\nNicolas Camara@nickscamara\\_](https://x.com/nickscamara_)\n\nNicolas Camara is the Chief Technology Officer (CTO) at Firecrawl.\nHe previously built and scaled Mendable, one of the pioneering "chat with your documents" apps,\nwhich had major Fortune 500 customers like Snapchat, Coinbase, and MongoDB.\nPrior to that, Nicolas built SideGuide, the first code-learning tool inside VS Code,\nand grew a community of 50,000 users. Nicolas studied Computer Science and has over 10 years of experience in building software.\n\n### More articles by Nicolas Camara\n\n[Extract website data using LLMs\\\\\n\\\\\nLearn how to use Firecrawl and Groq to extract structured data from a web page in a few lines of code.](/blog/data-extraction-using-llms) [Firecrawl x Dify.AI: Add web data to your RAG applications\\\\\n\\\\\nLearn how Firecrawl integrates with Dify.AI to provide web data to AI applications.](/blog/firecrawl-x-dify-ai-add-web-data-to-your-rag-applications) [Launch Week I / Day 6: LLM Extract (v1)\\\\\n\\\\\nExtract structured data from your web pages using the extract format in /scrape.](/blog/launch-week-i-day-6-llm-extract) [Launch Week I / Day 7: Crawl Webhooks (v1)\\\\\n\\\\\nNew /crawl webhook support.                                                                 Our first Launch Week is over! See the recap ðŸš€

                                                                September 1, 2024

                                                                â€¢

                                                                Nicolas Camara

                                                                Launch Week I / Day 7: Crawl Webhooks (v1)

                                                                Welcome to Day 7 of Firecrawlâ€™s Launch Week! Weâ€™re excited to introduce new /crawl webhook support.

                                                                \n

                                                                Crawl Webhook

                                                                \n

                                                                You can now pass a webhook parameter to the /crawl endpoint. This will send a POST request to the URL you specify when the crawl is started, updated and completed.

                                                                \n

                                                                The webhook will now trigger for every page crawled and not just the whole result at the end.

                                                                \n

                                                                \n

                                                                Webhook Events

                                                                \n

                                                                There are now 4 types of events:

                                                                \n
                                                                  \n
                                                                • crawl.started - Triggered when the crawl is started.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • crawl.page - Triggered for every page crawled.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • crawl.completed - Triggered when the crawl is completed to let you know itâ€™s done.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • crawl.failed - Triggered when the crawl fails.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                \n

                                                                Webhook Response

                                                                \n
                                                                  \n
                                                                • success - If the webhook was successful in crawling the page correctly.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • type - The type of event that occurred.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • id - The ID of the crawl.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • data - The data that was scraped (Array). This will only be non empty on crawl.page and will contain 1 item if the page was scraped successfully. The response is the same as the /scrape endpoint.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                • error - If the webhook failed, this will contain the error message.
                                                                  • \n
                                                                \n

                                                                Learn More

                                                                \n

                                                                Learn more about the webhook in our documentation.

                                                                Article updated recently

                                                                ðŸ”¥

                                                                Start scraping web data for your AI apps today.
                                                                No credit card needed.

Nicolas studied Computer Science and has over 10 years of experience in building software.

                                                                  We are excited to share our latest updates from June!

                                                                  \n

                                                                  \n
                                                                    \n
                                                                  • New Integrations live with Gamma, Dify, Praison, and Flowise

                                                                  • New tutorials and examples out
                                                                    • \n
                                                                  • Platform Improvements
                                                                    • \n
                                                                  \n

                                                                  Integrations

                                                                  \n

                                                                  Weâ€™ve been busy collaborating with some amazing partners to bring the power of Firecrawl to more platforms and users. Here are all of our current integrations:

                                                                  \n

                                                                  \n
                                                                    \n
                                                                  • Authenticated Web Scraping: One of our most requested features is now live! With the new headers option, you can forward authentication cookies to scrape data behind auth walls. No more barriers to the data you need.
                                                                    • \n
                                                                  • Improved Metadata for Scraped Pages: Weâ€™ve further enriched the metadata returned for each scraped page.

Nicolas studied Computer Science and has over 10 years of experience in building software.

[See the recap ðŸš€](blog/firecrawl-launch-week-1-recap)\n\nAug 6, 2024\n\nâ€¢\n\n[![Eric Ciarla image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/eric-img.jpeg)Eric Ciarla](https://x.com/ericciarla)\n\n# Your IP got blocked or banned? Here is how to unblock it\n\nIP blocks can occur due to various reasons, including spamming, unauthorized link posting, excessive web scraping, or accessing geo-restricted content.\nIf your IP was temporarily blocked or banned, all you might need to do is wait for the block to be lifted. If you donâ€™t know when the block will be lifted or if youâ€™re in a position where you canâ€™t wait, you can try the following methods:\n\n### Utilize VPN\n\n1. Download and install a reliable VPN. We recommend using [NordVPN](https://nordvpn.com/).\n2. Select a server location that is geographically close to you.\n3. Connect to the VPN to bypass the IP ban.\n\n### Clear Digital Footprint\n\n1. Clear your browserâ€™s cache and cookies.\n2. Delete any residual program data from relevant folders.\n3. Clean up registry entries related to the blocked application or website.\n\n### Modify MAC Address\n\n1. Access network settings\n2. Change adapter options\n3. Configure network address\n4. Generate and apply new MAC address\n\n### IP Blocking while Web Scraping?\n\n1. Use a proxy. We recommend using ISP proxyies (for speed) or mobile proxy services (for reliability).\n2. Use a VPN.\n3. Use a web scraper service that takes care of rotating IP addresses for you like [Firecrawl](/).\n\nProxies are often considered the most effective tool for bypassing blocks due to their ability to mask IP addresses and provide access to geo-restricted content. They offer a wide range of IP addresses and locations, making it difficult for websites to detect and block automated activities.\n\nTo avoid the hassle of IP blocks during web scraping, consider using a service like [Firecrawl](/). It automatically rotates proxies, eliminating the need to manage the complexities of web scraping yourself.\n\nArticle updated recently\n\n[ðŸ”¥](/)\n\n## Ready to _Build?_\n\nStart scraping web data for your AI apps today.\n\nNo credit card needed.\n\n[Get Started](/signin)\n\n[Talk to us](https://calendly.com/d/cj83-ngq-knk/meet-firecrawl)\n\n## About the Author\n\n[![Eric Ciarla image](https://www.firecrawl.dev/eric-img.jpeg)\\\\\nEric Ciarla@ericciarla](https://x.com/ericciarla)\n\nEric Ciarla is the Chief Operating Officer (COO) of Firecrawl and leads marketing. He also worked on Mendable.ai and sold it to companies like Snapchat, Coinbase, and MongoDB.\nPreviously worked at Ford and Fracta as a Data Scientist.                                                                     Our first Launch Week is over! See the recap ðŸš€

                                                                    Aug 6, 2024

                                                                    â€¢

                                                                    Eric Ciarla

                                                                    Your IP got blocked or banned? Here is how to unblock it

                                                                    IP blocks can occur due to various reasons, including spamming, unauthorized link posting, excessive web scraping, or accessing geo-restricted content.\nIf your IP was temporarily blocked or banned, all you might need to do is wait for the block to be lifted. If you donâ€™t know when the block will be lifted or if youâ€™re in a position where you canâ€™t wait, you can try the following methods:

                                                                    \n

                                                                    Utilize VPN

                                                                    \n
                                                                      \n
                                                                    1. Download and install a reliable VPN. We recommend using NordVPN.
                                                                      2. \n
                                                                    2. Select a server location that is geographically close to you.
                                                                      3. \n
                                                                    3. Connect to the VPN to bypass the IP ban.
                                                                      4. \n
                                                                    \n

                                                                    Clear Digital Footprint

                                                                    \n
                                                                      \n
                                                                    1. Clear your browserâ€™s cache and cookies.
                                                                      2. \n
                                                                    2. Delete any residual program data from relevant folders.
                                                                      3. \n
                                                                    3. Clean up registry entries related to the blocked application or website.
                                                                      4. \n
                                                                    \n

                                                                    Modify MAC Address

                                                                    \n
                                                                      \n
                                                                    1. Access network settings
                                                                      2. \n
                                                                    2. Change adapter options
                                                                      3. \n
                                                                    3. Configure network address
                                                                      4. \n
                                                                    4. Generate and apply new MAC address
                                                                      5. \n
                                                                    \n

                                                                    IP Blocking while Web Scraping?

                                                                    \n
                                                                      \n
                                                                    1. Use a proxy. We recommend using ISP proxyies (for speed) or mobile proxy services (for reliability).
                                                                      2. \n
                                                                    2. Use a VPN.
                                                                      3. \n
                                                                    3. Use a web scraper service that takes care of rotating IP addresses for you like Firecrawl.
                                                                      4. \n
                                                                    \n

                                                                    Proxies are often considered the most effective tool for bypassing blocks due to their ability to mask IP addresses and provide access to geo-restricted content. They offer a wide range of IP addresses and locations, making it difficult for websites to detect and block automated activities.

                                                                    \n

                                                                    To avoid the hassle of IP blocks during web scraping, consider using a service like Firecrawl. It automatically rotates proxies, eliminating the need to manage the complexities of web scraping yourself.

He also worked on Mendable.ai and sold it to companies like Snapchat, Coinbase, and MongoDB. \n Previously worked at Ford and Fracta as a Data Scientist. Eric also co-founded SideGuide, a tool for learning code within VS Code with 50,000 users.
